repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - National Watershed Management
            and Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was unsatisfactory,
            with modest institutional development impacts. Nonetheless,
            sustainability is likely, based on an apparently, continual
            commitment by the Government, in using the improved
            watershed methodologies, developed under the project,
            despite the need for stronger economic returns to
            investments in projects like this one. Both performances
            were also rated unsatisfactory; the Bank failed to provide
            adequate supervision, and, the Borrower failed to follow up
            preparation, and implementation with a detailed project
            plan, and training program to prepare the implementing
            agencies with the project work. Lessons reinforce the need
            for government commitments in results-oriented,
            demand-driven projects, as well as stakeholders'
            involvement in planning project activities, such as
            conservation, and village infrastructure works, to attain
            the expected project development. Yet, and although quality
            at entry is considered partially satisfactory, based on a
            good project design responsive to government priorities for
            promoting sustainable land use systems, certain activities,
            such as preparation of the implementation plan, and the
            bidding process for selection of consultants, should be
            correctly sequenced, started prior to loan effectiveness.
            Furthermore, the weak monitoring and evaluation,
            particularly regarding socioeconomic aspects, was a lost
            opportunity to assess project interventions; and,
            complementary farm activities should increase incomes, e.g.,
            livestock production becomes an effective complement to crop production.

5079499.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - National Watershed Management
            and Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main goals of the project will be to
            improve the living standards of poor upland farmers by
            improving and restoring the productive potential of their
            resource base and to improve watershed environmental quality
            and protect downstream watershed resources.  The project
            will inter alia support:  (a) institutional strengthening to
            improve the National Watershed Development Program
            (regreening and reforestation) guidelines and policies,
            overall coordination and operational support; (b)
            development of the Upper Cimanuk watershed; and (c)
            investment support for the regreening and reforestation
            program.  The national institutional strengthening component
            will provide support for improvement of planning, management
            and natural resources information systems, the creation of a
            multi-disciplinary upland research program and training and
            extension.  The Upper Cimanuk Watershed Conservation and
            Development component will stabilize critical areas in the
            Upper Cimanuk watershed (West Java) by supporting the
            introduction of improved farming systems on 15,750 ha of
            arable land, combined with soil conservation practices, road
            upgrading and drainage rehabilitation.  The Cimanuk
            component will serve as the initial implementation area for
            the procedural changes and technical approaches promoted by
            the project under the national regreening and reforestation program.
